title: The Impact of Upward Social Comparison on Social Media on Appearance Anxiety: A Moderated Mediation Model
authors: Tian, J., Li, B., Zhang, R.
keyAssumptions: Previous research assumed general social comparison effects without examining specific mediating mechanisms or protective factors
keyHypotheses: Self-objectification mediates USC-appearance anxiety relationship; self-compassion moderates this pathway
strengths: Large sample (n=397); validated measures; clear mediation model; identifies both risk and protective factors
weaknesses: Cross-sectional design; limited cultural generalizability; focus on young adults rather than adolescents
citation: Tian, J., Li, B., & Zhang, R. (2024). The Impact of Upward Social Comparison on Social Media on Appearance Anxiety: A Moderated Mediation Model. Behavioral Sciences, 15(1), 8.
notes: Key finding: USC significantly predicts appearance anxiety (β = 0.546, p < 0.001); self-objectification mediates 21% of total effect

title: The Perfect Storm: A Developmental–Sociocultural Framework for the Role of Social Media in Adolescent Girls' Body Image Concerns and Mental Health
authors: Choukas-Bradley, S., Nesi, J., et al.
journal: Clinical Child and Family Psychology Review
keyAssumptions: Previous research treated social media effects as gender-neutral or focused only on screen time
keyHypotheses: Social media features intersect with developmental and sociocultural factors to create 'perfect storm' for girls' body image concerns
strengths: Comprehensive theoretical framework; strong literature synthesis; gender-specific approach; identifies body image as key mediator
weaknesses: Theoretical rather than empirical; limited examination of protective factors; focus primarily on girls
citation: Choukas-Bradley, S., et al. (2022). The Perfect Storm: A Developmental–Sociocultural Framework for the Role of Social Media in Adolescent Girls' Body Image Concerns and Mental Health. Clinical Child and Family Psychology Review, 25, 681-701.
notes: Establishes that SM features (idealized images, quantifiable feedback) intersect with developmental factors and gender socialization

title: Body Image and Self-Esteem in Indian and Italian University Students: Cross-Cultural Insights for Psychiatric Well-Being
authors: Abdoli, M., Nayak, O., Fadia, A., Rairikar, M., De Sousa, A., Cotrufo, P.
keyAssumptions: Western-derived body image measures and concepts assumed universally applicable across cultures
keyHypotheses: Cultural contexts shape body image and self-esteem as psychological constructs affecting mental health
strengths: Large cross-cultural sample (n=767); standardized measures; clear cultural differences identified; clinical relevance
weaknesses: Limited to two countries; university student sample; cross-sectional design
citation: Abdoli, M., et al. (2025). Body Image and Self-Esteem in Indian and Italian University Students: Cross-Cultural Insights for Psychiatric Well-Being. Psychiatry International, 6(2), 40.
notes: Indian students showed higher self-esteem and more positive body image; cultural values provide protective effects

title: The Impact of Colonial Beauty Standards on the Ethnic Identity and Mental Health of Filipina Americans
keyAssumptions: Beauty standards research often treated ethnic minorities as monolithic without examining colonial histories
keyHypotheses: Colonial Eurocentric beauty standards affect ethnic identity formation and mental health through intergenerational transmission
strengths: Qualitative phenomenological approach; narrative analysis; identifies specific themes; addresses understudied population
weaknesses: Small sample (n=14); limited generalizability; thesis rather than peer-reviewed publication
citation: Tirona, C.M.G. (2023). The Impact of Colonial Beauty Standards on the Ethnic Identity and Mental Health of Filipina Americans. Master's thesis, San Francisco State University.
notes: Six themes identified including media overrepresentation, familial reinforcement, mental health impacts, and ethnic identity complications

title: Comparing the Impact of Screen Time Modes on Body Image for Men and Women
keyAssumptions: Prior research assumed uniform effects of screen time across genders and activities
keyHypotheses: Different screen time activities have differential effects on body image by gender
strengths: Platform-specific analysis; gender comparison; literature review approach
weaknesses: Preprint status; limited original data; high school student author
citation: Zhou, N. (2024). Comparing the Impact of Screen Time Modes on Body Image for Men and Women. Research Archive of Rising Scholars, 1436.
notes: Social media negative for both genders; TV viewing affects women only; gaming shows no significant correlation

title: Impact of Korean Wave on Eating Disorders: A Comparative Study
keyAssumptions: Pop culture influences assumed primarily Western; East Asian beauty standards' global impact understudied
keyHypotheses: Korean Wave popularity influences eating behaviors and body image ideals internationally
strengths: Novel cultural focus; comparative design; uses validated eating disorder measure (EDE-Q 6.0)
weaknesses: Small sample (n=100); limited demographic diversity; cross-sectional design
citation: Kumari, A. (2024). Impact of Korean Wave on Eating Disorders: A Comparative Study. International Journal of Indian Psychology, 12(1), 133.
notes: Korean Wave followers scored significantly higher on eating disorder scales than non-followers

title: Effects of Social Media Social Comparisons and Identity Processes on Body Image Satisfaction in Late Adolescence
keyAssumptions: Prior work treated body image as unidimensional; didn't examine identity development interactions
keyHypotheses: Identity development interacts with social media comparison to affect body image domains differently
strengths: Domain-specific body image analysis; identity development focus; late adolescent sample (n=354)
weaknesses: Single country sample; cross-sectional design; limited generalizability
citation: Croatian research team (2023). Effects of Social Media Social Comparisons and Identity Processes on Body Image Satisfaction in Late Adolescence. PMC, Article 10508212.
notes: Different body image domains show distinct patterns; identity commitment more important for attribution, social comparison crucial for appearance/weight
